Utterance: Hi again, it's good to see you back. How have you been since our last session?
Hi, Ellie! I've been okay, just busy with work and the kids.
That sounds like a lot to manage. Have you had any moments to relax or take care of yourself?
Not really, I feel like I’m always on the go. But I did manage to watch a movie with the kids last weekend.
That’s great! Spending time with them can be a wonderful way to unwind. What movie did you watch?
We watched a Disney movie. They loved it, and it was nice to see them smile.
That sounds like a lovely experience. How did it feel for you to see them happy?
It made me happy too. It’s nice to see them enjoying themselves, especially with everything going on.
I can imagine. Last time, you mentioned feeling a bit overwhelmed with parenting. Have those feelings changed at all?
I think I’m getting better at it, but some days are definitely harder than others.
What do you think has helped you feel a bit better about parenting?
I’ve been trying to focus on the positives more. Like, I remind myself that my son is doing his best, and so am I.
That’s a fantastic mindset. What strategies have you been using to stay positive?
I try to celebrate the little victories. Like when my son learns something new, I make a big deal out of it.
That’s a wonderful approach! Recognizing small successes can really help shift your perspective. Have you noticed any changes in your son as well?
Yeah, he seems more confident. It’s like he’s realizing he can do things, even if they’re challenging.
That’s incredible to hear! It sounds like you’re both making progress. Are there any challenges you’re currently facing that we can talk about?
Well, I still struggle with my mom. She keeps pushing me to do things her way, and it frustrates me.
It sounds like that’s still a source of stress for you. How do you usually handle those conversations with her?
I try to stay calm, but sometimes I just snap. It’s hard to keep my cool when she doesn’t respect my choices.
That’s understandable. It can be challenging when someone close to us doesn’t validate our decisions. Would you like to explore some coping strategies for those situations?
Yes, I think that would help.
One strategy could be to set boundaries. Have you thought about what boundaries you might want to establish with her?
I guess I could tell her that I need her to trust my decisions as a parent.
That’s a good start. Setting clear expectations can help reduce tension. How do you think she would respond to that?
She might be defensive at first, but I think she’ll come around eventually.
It’s great that you have hope for that. Would you like to practice how you might approach that conversation?
Sure, that could be helpful.
Let’s role-play. You can start by expressing your feelings, and I’ll respond as your mom.
Okay, um, “Mom, I appreciate your advice, but I need you to trust my decisions as a parent.”
“But I just want what’s best for you and the kids. I worry that you’re not doing enough.”
“I understand that, but I’m doing my best, and I need you to support me rather than criticize me.”
“I guess I can try to do that, but it’s hard for me to let go.”
“I know it’s hard, but I promise I’m trying to be the best mom I can be, and I need your support.”
How did that feel for you?
It felt good to voice my feelings. I hope she’ll understand.
That’s a positive step. Remember, it’s about expressing your needs while also being empathetic to her concerns.
Right, I’ll keep that in mind.
Is there anything else you’d like to discuss today?
I’ve been thinking about going back to school to further my psychology studies.
That sounds exciting! What’s motivating you to pursue that?
I feel like I need to challenge myself and grow. Plus, I want to be a better role model for my kids.
That’s a great motivation. Have you thought about what steps you might take to get started?
I’ve looked into some online courses, but I’m worried about balancing everything.
It’s understandable to feel that way. Perhaps we can work on a plan to help you manage your time effectively.
That would be helpful!
Let’s set some realistic goals for you. How many hours a week do you think you could dedicate to studying?
Maybe three to four hours? I could do a couple of evenings after the kids are in bed.
That sounds reasonable. What about creating a schedule to keep track of your study times?
I could definitely try that. I’m a bit of a planner, so it might help me stay organized.
That’s a great idea! Planning can help reduce anxiety about fitting everything in.
I feel more motivated just talking about it!
I’m glad to hear that. It’s important to nurture those feelings of motivation.
Thank you for your help, Ellie.
You’re welcome! I’m looking forward to hearing about your progress next time.
Me too! See you next week!
See you then! Take care.
